segment.source: Create a simple Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game with DirectX
segment.target: Create a simple Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game with DirectX

segment.source: In this set of tutorials, you learn how to create a basic Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game with DirectX and C++.
segment.target: In this set of tutorials, you learn how to create a basic Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game with DirectX and C++.

segment.source: DirectX game sample
segment.target: DirectX game sample

segment.source: game sample, Universal Windows Platform (UWP)
segment.target: game sample, Universal Windows Platform (UWP)

segment.source: Direct3D 11 game
segment.target: Direct3D 11 game

segment.source: Create a simple Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game with DirectX
segment.target: Create a simple Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game with DirectX

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: In this set of tutorials, you learn how to create a basic Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game with DirectX and C++.
segment.target: In this set of tutorials, you learn how to create a basic Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game with DirectX and C++.

segment.source: We cover all the major parts of a game, including the processes for loading assets such as arts and meshes, creating a main game loop, implementing a simple rendering pipeline, and adding sound and controls.
segment.target: We cover all the major parts of a game, including the processes for loading assets such as arts and meshes, creating a main game loop, implementing a simple rendering pipeline, and adding sound and controls.

segment.source: We show you the UWP game development techniques and considerations.
segment.target: We show you the UWP game development techniques and considerations.

segment.source: We don't provide a complete end-to-end game.
segment.target: We don't provide a complete end-to-end game.

segment.source: Rather, we focus on key UWP DirectX game development concepts, and call out Windows Runtime specific considerations around those concepts.
segment.target: Rather, we focus on key UWP DirectX game development concepts, and call out Windows Runtime specific considerations around those concepts.

segment.source: Objective
segment.target: Objective

segment.source: To use the basic concepts and components of a UWP DirectX game, and to become more comfortable designing UWP games with DirectX.
segment.target: To use the basic concepts and components of a UWP DirectX game, and to become more comfortable designing UWP games with DirectX.

segment.source: What you need to know before starting
segment.target: What you need to know before starting

segment.source: Before we get started with this tutorial, you need to be familiar with these subjects.
segment.target: Before we get started with this tutorial, you need to be familiar with these subjects.

segment.source: Microsoft C++ with Component Extensions (C++/CX).
segment.target: Microsoft C++ with Component Extensions (C++/CX).

segment.source: This is an update to Microsoft C++ that incorporates automatic reference counting, and is the language for developing a UWP games with DirectX 11.1 or later versions.
segment.target: This is an update to Microsoft C++ that incorporates automatic reference counting, and is the language for developing a UWP games with DirectX 11.1 or later versions.

segment.source: Basic linear algebra and Newtonian physics concepts.
segment.target: Basic linear algebra and Newtonian physics concepts.

segment.source: Basic graphics programming terminology.
segment.target: Basic graphics programming terminology.

segment.source: Basic Windows programming concepts.
segment.target: Basic Windows programming concepts.

segment.source: Basic familiarity with the Direct2D and Direct3D 11 APIs.
segment.target: Basic familiarity with the Direct2D and Direct3D 11 APIs.

segment.source: The Windows Store Direct3D shooting game sample
segment.target: The Windows Store Direct3D shooting game sample

segment.source: This sample implements a simple first-person shooting gallery, where the player fires balls at moving targets.
segment.target: This sample implements a simple first-person shooting gallery, where the player fires balls at moving targets.

segment.source: Hitting each target awards a set number of points, and the player can progress through 6 levels of increasing challenge.
segment.target: Hitting each target awards a set number of points, and the player can progress through 6 levels of increasing challenge.

segment.source: At the end of the levels, the points are tallied, and the player is awarded a final score.
segment.target: At the end of the levels, the points are tallied, and the player is awarded a final score.

segment.source: The sample demonstrates the game concepts:
segment.target: The sample demonstrates the game concepts:

segment.source: Interoperation between DirectX 11.1 and the Windows Runtime
segment.target: Interoperation between DirectX 11.1 and the Windows Runtime

segment.source: A first-person 3D perspective and camera
segment.target: A first-person 3D perspective and camera

segment.source: Stereoscopic 3D effects
segment.target: Stereoscopic 3D effects

segment.source: Collision detection between objects in 3D
segment.target: Collision detection between objects in 3D

segment.source: Handling player input for mouse, touch, and Xbox 360 controller controls
segment.target: Handling player input for mouse, touch, and Xbox 360 controller controls

segment.source: Audio mixing and playback
segment.target: Audio mixing and playback

segment.source: A basic game state machine
segment.target: A basic game state machine

segment.source: the game sample in action
segment.target: the game sample in action

segment.source: Topic
segment.target: Topic

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Set up the game project
segment.target: Set up the game project

segment.source: The first step in assembling your game is to set up a project in Microsoft Visual Studio in such a way that you minimize the amount of code infrastructure work you need to do.
segment.target: The first step in assembling your game is to set up a project in Microsoft Visual Studio in such a way that you minimize the amount of code infrastructure work you need to do.

segment.source: You can save yourself a lot of time and hassle by using the right template and configuring the project specifically for game development.
segment.target: You can save yourself a lot of time and hassle by using the right template and configuring the project specifically for game development.

segment.source: We step you through the setup and configuration of a simple game project.
segment.target: We step you through the setup and configuration of a simple game project.

segment.source: Define the game's UWP app framework
segment.target: Define the game's UWP app framework

segment.source: The first part of coding a UWP with DirectX game is building the framework that lets the game object interact with Windows.
segment.target: The first part of coding a UWP with DirectX game is building the framework that lets the game object interact with Windows.

segment.source: This includes Windows Runtime properties like suspend/resume event handling, window focus, and snapping, plus as the events, interactions and transitions for the user interface.
segment.target: This includes Windows Runtime properties like suspend/resume event handling, window focus, and snapping, plus as the events, interactions and transitions for the user interface.

segment.source: We go over how the sample game is structured, and how it defines the high-level state machine for the player and system interaction.
segment.target: We go over how the sample game is structured, and how it defines the high-level state machine for the player and system interaction.

segment.source: Define the main game object
segment.target: Define the main game object

segment.source: Now, we look at the details of the game sample's main object and how the rules it implements translate into interactions with the game world.
segment.target: Now, we look at the details of the game sample's main object and how the rules it implements translate into interactions with the game world.

segment.source: Assemble the rendering framework
segment.target: Assemble the rendering framework

segment.source: Now, it's time to look at how the sample game uses that structure and state to display its graphics.
segment.target: Now, it's time to look at how the sample game uses that structure and state to display its graphics.

segment.source: Here, we look at how to implement a rendering framework, starting from the initialization of the graphics device through the presentation of the graphics objects for display.
segment.target: Here, we look at how to implement a rendering framework, starting from the initialization of the graphics device through the presentation of the graphics objects for display.

segment.source: Add a user interface
segment.target: Add a user interface

segment.source: You've seen how the sample game implements the main game object as well as the basic rendering framework.
segment.target: You've seen how the sample game implements the main game object as well as the basic rendering framework.

segment.source: Now, let's look at how the sample game provides feedback about game state to the player.
segment.target: Now, let's look at how the sample game provides feedback about game state to the player.

segment.source: Here, you learn how you can add simple menu options and heads-up display components on top of the 3-D graphics pipeline output.
segment.target: Here, you learn how you can add simple menu options and heads-up display components on top of the 3-D graphics pipeline output.

segment.source: Add controls
segment.target: Add controls

segment.source: Now, we take a look at how the game sample implements move-look controls in a 3-D game, and how to develop basic touch, mouse, and game controller controls.
segment.target: Now, we take a look at how the game sample implements move-look controls in a 3-D game, and how to develop basic touch, mouse, and game controller controls.

segment.source: Add sound
segment.target: Add sound

segment.source: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the XAudio2 APIs.
segment.target: In this step, we examine how the shooting game sample creates an object for sound playback using the XAudio2 APIs.

segment.source: Extend the game sample
segment.target: Extend the game sample

segment.source: Congratulations!
segment.target: Congratulations!

segment.source: At this point, you understand the key components of a basic UWP DirectX 3D game.
segment.target: At this point, you understand the key components of a basic UWP DirectX 3D game.

segment.source: You can set up the framework for a game, including the view provider and rendering pipeline, and implement a basic game loop.
segment.target: You can set up the framework for a game, including the view provider and rendering pipeline, and implement a basic game loop.

segment.source: You can also create a basic user interface overlay, and incorporate sounds and controls.
segment.target: You can also create a basic user interface overlay, and incorporate sounds and controls.

segment.source: You're on your way to creating a game of your own, and here are some resources to further your knowledge of DirectX game development.
segment.target: You're on your way to creating a game of your own, and here are some resources to further your knowledge of DirectX game development.
